title: Create Textual-backed utility to edit issue
close_reason: Implemented dcat edit command with Textual TUI editor

title: Add -e --editor option to dcat create that opens the editor after issue creation
close_reason: Added -e/--editor flag to dcat create that opens the Textual editor after issue creation

title: Create Homebrew formula and tap for dogcat
description:
## Implementation Plan

### Approach
Use `uv run` as the execution mechanism. The Homebrew formula installs the dogcat source to libexec and creates a thin bin/dcat wrapper script that delegates to `uv run --no-dev --project <libexec> dcat "$@"`. uv handles Python, venv creation, and dependency resolution automatically.

### Tap repo
https://github.com/oroddlokken/tap (brew tap oroddlokken/tap)

### Child Issues (dependency order)
1. **39aq** Add LICENSE — CLOSED
2. **30vn** Create tap repo on GitHub — CLOSED (oroddlokken/tap)
3. **6cne** Tag v0.1.0 release — unblocked
4. **5wji** Write `Formula/dogcat.rb` — unblocked (30vn closed)
5. **2ved** Add install instructions to README — blocked by 5wji

### Formula Design
```ruby
class Dogcat < Formula
  desc "Git-backed issue tracking for AI agents"
  homepage "https://github.com/oroddlokken/dogcat"
  url "https://github.com/oroddlokken/dogcat/archive/refs/tags/v0.1.0.tar.gz"
  sha256 "<hash>"
  license "MIT"
  depends_on "uv"

  def install
    libexec.install Dir["*"]
    (bin/"dcat").write <<~BASH
      #!/bin/bash
      exec uv run --no-dev --project "#{libexec}" dcat "$@"
    BASH
  end

  test do
    system bin/"dcat", "--help"
  end
end
```

### Risk
On first run, uv creates .venv inside libexec. If permissions prevent this, fallback: set UV_PROJECT_ENVIRONMENT in wrapper to redirect venv to $HOME/.cache/dogcat/venv.
close_reason: Homebrew formula working, all child issues closed

title: Remove all code related to creating gitattributes files
close_reason: Removed all gitattributes-related code: the --no-gitattributes CLI option, the .gitattributes creation logic in init, and all test references.

title: Write the Homebrew formula (dogcat.rb)
description: Write Formula/dogcat.rb for the oroddlokken/homebrew-tap repo. The formula should: (1) clone the dogcat repo from a tagged release, (2) install the source to libexec, (3) create a bin/dcat wrapper script that runs 'uv run --project <libexec> dcat "$@"', (4) depend on uv. The wrapper lets uv handle the Python venv and all dependencies automatically.
close_reason: Formula written and verified working

title: Support external .dogcats directory via .dogcatrc config file
description: Allow users to place their .dogcats folder outside the repo by creating a .dogcatrc file in the repo root (or any parent directory). The file contains a single path pointing to the .dogcats directory. Supports relative and absolute paths. Discovery uses the same upward search pattern: look for .dogcatrc first, read the path from it, then fall back to searching for .dogcats/ directly.

If found, read the directory path from it and resolve it (handling relative paths relative to the .dogcatrc location). If no .dogcatrc is found, fall back to the current behavior of searching for a .dogcats/ directory.

In flat list mode, keep current behavior (closed parents hidden by default). The closed parent is already visually distinguished by the ✓ status icon.

title: Add a git integration guide command

Should cover things like: committing .dogcats changes, branching workflows, resolving merge conflicts in issues.jsonl, how to .gitignore the .dogcats directory if needed, and any best practices for integrating dogcat into a git-based workflow.

title: Rename skip_agent feature to no_agent for clarity
description:
The current naming is confusing:
- skip_agent: true metadata key is unclear
- --exclude-skip-agent CLI flag is a double-negative

Rename to:
- Metadata: no_agent: true
- Create/update flag: --no-agent (remove with --agent)
- List/ready filter: --agent-only

Files to update:
- src/dogcat/cli.py — CLI flags and filtering logic
- tests/test_dogcat_cli.py — update test names and assertions
- tests/test_models.py — update metadata key references

title: Update CLAUDE.md to use --agent-only flag
description: Update CLAUDE.md to instruct agents to use --agent-only when listing issues, so that issues marked with --no-agent are automatically excluded from agent workflows.
close_reason: Updated CLAUDE.md to use --agent-only flag

title: What happens if archived issues' IDs collide with new issues?
description: If issues are archived and then a new issue is created that gets assigned the same ID as a previously archived issue, what happens? Is there a collision/conflict? Does the system guard against this?
close_reason: Yes, collisions are possible after archive/prune. Collision checks only cover active issues in memory, not archived or pruned ones. Practical risk is low (~1/1.7M per attempt) but nonzero. Possible fixes: extend collision checks to archives, maintain a used-IDs registry, or add random entropy.

title: Demo command should use current folder name as namespace instead of hardcoded 'demo'
description: The demo command in demo.py hardcodes IDGenerator(prefix="demo") (line 47), whereas the normal create command in cli.py resolves the namespace from the project config via get_issue_prefix(dogcats_dir) (line 693). The demo command should derive the namespace from the current folder name (or project config) so that generated demo issue IDs match the project's namespace convention.
close_reason: Fixed double-prefixing: replaced IDGenerator with simple counter for id field, set namespace from get_issue_prefix(dogcats_dir) on all Issue constructors

title: Add 'add' and 'new' as aliases for dcat create

close_reason: Added 'add' and 'new' as aliases for dcat create with tests

title: dcat edit crashes on submit: subscripted generics in query_one
description: Running dcat edit and clicking submit raises TypeError: 'Subscripted generics cannot be used with class and instance checks' on Python 3.13. The _do_save method passes Select[str], Select[int] to query_one which internally does isinstance checks.
close_reason: Removed subscripted generics (Select[str], Select[int]) from query_one calls in _do_save, replacing with bare Select to fix Python 3.13 compatibility

title: What is the optimal way to use dogcat with git worktrees?
close_reason: Answered: best approach is native worktree auto-detection via git rev-parse --git-common-dir. Created dogcat-24kd to implement this, blocked by the .dogcatrc epic (dogcat-20pq).

title: Make parent field in edit form an interactive issue picker
description: Replace the read-only Static parent display in the edit form with an interactive widget that allows users to search and select other issues as the parent. When clicked, it should show a searchable list of available issues (excluding the current issue and its descendants to prevent cycles). Selecting an issue sets it as the parent; clearing the selection removes the parent.

title: Auto-detect git worktrees in find_dogcats_dir()
description: When the upward directory walk fails to find .dogcats/, fall back to checking the main worktree root via git rev-parse --git-common-dir. This makes dogcat transparent in linked worktrees without any manual setup (no symlinks or --dogcats-dir flags needed).
close_reason: Added git worktree fallback in find_dogcats_dir()

title: Add dcat init --use-existing-folder to create .dogcatrc for existing .dogcats directory
description: Add a --use-existing-folder option to dcat init that takes a path to an existing .dogcats directory and creates a .dogcatrc file pointing to it, without reinitializing. This is useful when a .dogcats directory already exists elsewhere and you want to link to it from a new repo. Should validate that the target path exists and contains a valid .dogcats directory (e.g., has issues.jsonl). Errors clearly if the path doesn't exist or isn't a valid dogcat directory.

Set up a GitHub Actions CI/CD pipeline that automates:
1. Building and releasing new versions of dogcat (triggered by version tags)
2. Automatically updating the Homebrew formula at github.com/oroddlokken/homebrew-tap

This epic covers the full release automation story from tag to published Homebrew formula.

title: Support pINT shorthand for --priority in create and update
description: Make the --priority/-p flag on create and update accept pINT notation (e.g., p1, p2, p0) in addition to bare integers. Currently -p only accepts INTEGER, so -p p1 fails. Both -p 1 and -p p1 should set priority to 1.
close_reason: Added _parse_priority_value parser supporting both INT and pINT notation for --priority flag on create and update

title: Update dcat create help examples to show --type and --priority flags
description: The dcat create help text currently only shows shorthand notation examples (bare digits, single letters). Add examples using the explicit --type/-t and --priority/-p flags so users can see both styles.
close_reason: Added -p INT, -p pINT, and -t flag examples to create help text; aligned comments; made arg help dynamic from constants

title: test pINT
close_reason: test issue, cleaning up

title: test pINT flag
close_reason: test issue

title: test bare int
close_reason: test issue

title: Explain the name in the README
Elaborate on --no-agent in README
Make e alias for edit and n alias for new
close_reason: Added hidden 'e' alias for edit and 'n' alias for new commands

title: Add FAQ to readme
Add 'dcat version' command
description: Add a 'dcat version' command that displays the current version number. Use importlib.metadata.version('dogcat') to retrieve the version.

title: Close reason embedded in notes field is fragile to parse
description: When closing an issue (storage.py:349), the reason is concatenated onto notes: issue.notes = (issue.notes or '') + '\n\nClosed: {reason}'. Then in cli.py:227-230, it's parsed back out with string splitting on 'Closed: '. This is brittle — if a user writes 'Closed: ' in their notes, parsing breaks. The close reason should be a dedicated field on Issue rather than embedded in free-text.
close_reason: Added dedicated close_reason field to Issue model with backward-compatible migration

title: storage.update() uses setattr with unvalidated keys
description: storage.py:308-318 — The update method blindly sets any key from the updates dict via setattr(issue, key, value) if hasattr(issue, key). This means callers can overwrite internal fields like id, namespace, full_id, created_at, or even comments without any guard. A malformed update dict could corrupt issue identity. There should be an allowlist of updatable fields.
close_reason: Added UPDATABLE_FIELDS allowlist to storage.update()

title: close() and delete() don't set updated_at
description: storage.py:346-351 (close) and storage.py:374-377 (delete) both modify the issue but neither set updated_at. Only update() at line 321 sets it. This means closed_at can be newer than updated_at, which is semantically wrong and could break time-based queries.
close_reason: Added updated_at assignment to close() and delete()

title: _detect_prefix_from_issues uses stdlib json instead of orjson
description: config.py:156-171 — This function imports json (stdlib) to read the JSONL file, while every other module uses orjson. This inconsistency means different JSON parsing behavior (orjson is stricter) and misses the performance benefit.
close_reason: Replaced stdlib json with orjson in _detect_prefix_from_issues for consistency and performance

title: Dependency and link queries are O(n) linear scans
description: storage.py:511, 529, etc. — All dependency and link queries scan the full _dependencies or _links list. With many dependencies this is inefficient. An index dict (dict[str, list[Dependency]]) keyed by issue_id and depends_on_id would make these O(1) lookups.
close_reason: Added index dicts for O(1) dependency and link lookups, replacing O(n) linear scans

title: get_default_operator() shells out to git on every call
description: cli.py:61-74 — subprocess.run(['git', 'config', 'user.email']) is called every time an issue is created, updated, closed, or deleted. There's no caching. This spawns a process per operation, adding latency. The result should be cached at least per CLI invocation.
close_reason: Added lru_cache to get_default_operator() so git subprocess is only spawned once per CLI invocation

title: _save() rewrites entire file on every mutation
description: storage.py:107-161 — Every single create, update, close, delete, add_dependency, remove_dependency, add_link, or remove_link triggers a full rewrite of every issue, dependency, and link. For a database with thousands of issues this becomes slow. An append-only approach (writing new records) with periodic compaction would be more efficient.
close_reason: Implemented append-only storage with auto-compaction

title: Redundant event_type assignment in StreamEmitter._compute_diff
description: stream.py:128-144 — event_type is set inside the per-field loop (line 133) but then reassigned after the loop (line 141). The inner assignment is dead code — it's always overwritten by the outer logic.
close_reason: Removed dead event_type assignment inside per-field loop; post-loop logic already handles it correctly

title: tree/table mutual exclusion validated too late in list command
description: cli.py:1290-1292 — The check for tree and table being mutually exclusive happens after all data has been fetched, filtered, and sorted. This should be at the top of the function before doing any work.
close_reason: Moved tree/table mutual exclusion check to top of list_issues function, before any data fetching

title: Dependency dataclass uses 'type' as field name, shadowing builtin
description: models.py:60 — type: DependencyType shadows the Python builtin type. While technically fine as a dataclass field, it's confusing in any context where you might need type().
close_reason: Renamed Dependency.type to Dependency.dep_type to avoid shadowing builtin

title: StreamEvent.changes has type: ignore annotation
description: stream.py:40 — The field uses dict[str, dict[str, Any]] with a type: ignore. This suggests the default factory and the annotation don't match cleanly. A proper type or wrapper would be cleaner.
close_reason: Removed type: ignore by using bare dict factory

title: Unusual list[str]() factory syntax in Issue dataclass
description: models.py:89,104,106 — Uses list[str]() as default factory which is valid Python 3.9+ but unusual and potentially confusing. list() or [] would be clearer.
close_reason: Replaced unusual list[str]() factory syntax with idiomatic list/dict factories

title: Standalone generate_issue_id() hardcodes length=4, ignores progressive scaling
description: idgen.py:93 — The standalone function always generates 4-char IDs, ignoring the progressive scaling logic. Only IDGenerator.generate_issue_id (line 200) respects scaling. If anyone calls the standalone function directly they'll get short IDs regardless of DB size.
close_reason: Added issue_count parameter to standalone generate_issue_id() so it uses progressive ID length scaling via get_id_length_for_count()

title: Docstring says config.yaml but code uses config.toml
description: config.py:101 — The get_issue_prefix docstring says 'issue_prefix from config.yaml' but the actual file is config.toml.
close_reason: Fixed docstring: config.yaml -> config.toml

title: Mutable list used as counter pattern in demo.py
description: demo.py:49 — Uses counter = [0] and comment_counter = [0] as mutable closures. This works but itertools.count() or a simple class would be more Pythonic.
close_reason: Replaced mutable list counters with itertools.count() for more Pythonic pattern

title: Cycle detection compares lists for uniqueness with O(n*m) cost
description: deps.py:147 — 'if cycle not in cycles' checks list membership in a list of lists, which is O(n*m) per cycle found. For large graphs this could be slow. Converting cycles to tuples and using a set would be more efficient.
close_reason: Changed cycle dedup to use set of tuples for O(1) lookups

title: edit.py uses issue.id instead of issue.full_id for update call
description: edit.py:413 — self._storage.update(self._issue.id, updates) uses the short id instead of full_id. This works because resolve_id matches partial IDs, but it's inconsistent with the rest of the codebase and could match the wrong issue if two namespaces share a hash.
close_reason: Changed self._issue.id to self._issue.full_id in edit.py update call for consistency and correctness

title: CLI commands print user-provided partial ID instead of resolved full ID
description: cli.py:1607 and others — Commands like update and close print the raw issue_id argument (which may be partial) instead of the resolved issue.full_id. The resolved full ID would be more informative for the user.
close_reason: Changed success messages in update, close, delete, and label commands to print resolved issue.full_id instead of raw partial ID

title: Quoted positional arguments starting with -- are parsed as options
description: When creating an issue with a title like '"--tree and --table ..."', Typer/Click still interprets --tree as an option flag even though it's inside a quoted string. This means titles containing double-dash prefixed words fail with 'No such option'. Likely needs '--' sentinel support or escaping in the argument parser.
close_reason: Documented -- sentinel usage in create command docstring

title: Add support for type/priority shorthands in dcat new
description: Similar to how it works in dcat create
close_reason: Implemented type/priority shorthands for dcat new, matching dcat create behavior

title: Rewrite demo.py to use CLI/public API instead of direct storage calls
description:
demo.py bypasses the CLI layer entirely, calling storage.create(), storage.update(), storage.close() etc. directly. This means:

1. **ID generation** - Uses simple sequential IDs (0001, 0002, ...) instead of IDGenerator which hashes title+timestamp. Demo data doesn't look like real data.
2. **Operator attribution** - Manually sets created_by/updated_by/closed_by instead of relying on CLI auto-detection from git config.
3. **No reference validation** - CLI validates parent, duplicate_of, and dependency targets exist before creating. Demo bypasses this.
4. **Comments injected directly** - Passes comments list directly via storage.update(), bypassing the proper comment-adding path.
5. **No dependency pre-validation** - CLI checks dependency targets exist before issue creation (fail-fast). Demo calls storage.add_dependency() directly.

The demo should exercise the same code paths as real usage so it can catch bugs in the CLI layer and produce realistic-looking data.
close_reason: Rewrote demo.py to use IDGenerator for hash-based IDs, CLI-style comment format, reference validation for parents/duplicates/deps, and proper close/delete flows

title: Improve labels
description: Epic for improving label support across dogcat: add labels to update command, add a labels discovery command, show labels in TUI and list output, and support multi-label filtering.
close_reason: All child issues completed

title: Add --labels option to update command
description: Add a --labels flag to the update command that replaces the entire label list. Comma-separated, consistent with how create --labels works.
close_reason: Added --labels option to update command

title: Add dcat labels command to display all labels
description: Add a new 'labels' command that lists all unique labels used across all issues, with optional counts.
close_reason: Added dcat labels command with counts and --json support

title: Show labels in new/edit TUI
description: Add label display and editing support to the Textual-based new issue form and edit issue form.
close_reason: Added labels input to TUI editor

title: Show labels in dcat list output
description: Display labels in the brief, table, and tree list formats. Currently labels only appear in dcat show.
close_reason: Labels now shown in brief, table, and tree output

title: Support multi-label filtering in dcat list
description: Allow filtering by multiple labels in dcat list, e.g. --label a,b or repeated --label flags. Currently only single-label filtering is supported.
close_reason: Support comma-separated multi-label filtering with OR semantics

title: Archive command discards event history for both archived and remaining issues
description:
When `dcat archive` runs, it loses mutation history in two ways:

1. **Archived issues**: The archive file (`.dogcats/archive/closed-<timestamp>.jsonl`) only writes the final snapshot of each issue via `issue_to_dict()`. All intermediate append-only records (status changes, priority updates, reassignments, etc.) are discarded.

2. **Remaining open issues**: After removing archived issues from memory, `_save()` is called which compacts the main `issues.jsonl` file — rewriting it with only current state. This destroys the append-only event history for all surviving issues too.

**Expected behavior**: Archive should preserve the full append-only event log for archived issues in the archive file, and should not compact away the history of open issues that remain in the main file.

**Root cause**: `_save()` (storage.py) always does a full rewrite. The archive command at cli.py:3085 calls `_save()` unconditionally after removing archived issues from memory.
close_reason: Fixed archive to preserve full append-only event history for both archived and remaining issues by splitting raw JSONL lines instead of writing snapshots and compacting

title: Add record_type discriminator field to JSONL records
description:
The issues.jsonl file stores multiple record types (issues, dependencies, links) in the same file, but there is no explicit field to distinguish them. The code infers the type by checking which fields are present (e.g. has from_id+to_id = link, has issue_id+depends_on_id = dependency, else = issue).

Adding a `record_type` field (values: 'issue', 'dependency', 'link') to each line would make the file self-describing and easier to parse from external tools without knowing the schema.

Using `record_type` rather than `action_type` since there's already an `op` field for add/remove actions — avoids confusion.

**Field-sniffing is duplicated in 3 places:**
- `storage.py:_load()` (~line 102) — primary parsing
- `cli.py` archive command (~line 3055) — duplicated for archive filtering
- `config.py:_detect_prefix_from_issues()` (~line 165) — **bug: doesn't filter at all**, tries to read `id` from dep/link records

**Consolidation:** Add a shared `classify_record(data)` helper in `models.py` that checks for explicit `record_type` first, falls back to field-sniffing for backward compat. Replace all 3 locations with calls to it.

**Write side:** Add `record_type` to `issue_to_dict()`, `_dep_record()`, `_link_record()`, and the inline dicts in `_save()`.

**Note:** `stream.py` does NOT duplicate parsing — it delegates to `JSONLStorage`, so no changes needed there.

**Backward compatibility**: Existing records without a `record_type` field must continue to be parsed correctly. The helper falls back to field-sniffing when `record_type` is absent.
close_reason: Added record_type discriminator to all JSONL records, classify_record() helper with backward-compatible fallback, consolidated field-sniffing in storage/cli/config

title: close and delete commands write two events each: action then update for operator field
description: In cli.py, both close (line 1677-1681) and delete (line 1726-1731) call the storage action first, then immediately call storage.update() to set the operator field (closed_by / deleted_by). This produces duplicate events in the append-only log. The fix is to pass the operator into storage.close() and storage.delete() directly so only one record is written per action.
close_reason: Added closed_by/deleted_by params to storage.close() and storage.delete(), removed duplicate storage.update() calls from CLI

title: Support --priority string
description:
update --priority medium
create --priority critical

Based on the values in constants.py
close_reason: Extended --priority to accept string names (critical/high/medium/low/minimal) alongside existing 0-4 and p0-p4 formats

title: Make dcat create support --title
close_reason: Duplicate of dogcat-2val — --title flag already implemented

title: Remove uv dependency from Homebrew formula
description: The current Homebrew formula uses `depends_on "uv"` which forces users to install uv just to use dogcat. This is intrusive since uv is not a common Homebrew dependency. Switch to `depends_on "python@3.13"` and use Python's built-in venv + pip for installation instead, which is the standard Homebrew pattern for Python packages.

title: Add regression tests for loading versioned issues.jsonl fixtures
description:
Add backward-compatibility regression tests that verify older JSONL files still load correctly as the format evolves.

## Components

### 1. Fixture generator (`just generate-fixture`)
- A justfile target that runs a test helper (`tests/generate_fixture.py`) to create a representative `issues.jsonl` covering all issue types, statuses, dependencies, links, and comments using the storage/models API
- Output goes to `tests/fixtures/v<version>_issues.jsonl` (version derived from git tags)
- This is a test utility, not user-facing (not part of demo.py)

### 2. Frozen fixtures (`tests/fixtures/`)
- Each release has a committed fixture file (e.g. `v0.3.0_issues.jsonl`)
- These never change once committed — they represent the format at that point in time

### 3. Regression test (`tests/test_regression.py`)
- Discovers all fixture files in `tests/fixtures/`
- Loads each with `JSONLStorage` and asserts: no errors, correct issue counts, all types/statuses/deps/links survive the round-trip
- Runs as part of normal CI
close_reason: Implemented fixture generator (tests/generate_fixture.py), 12 frozen fixtures (v0.1.0–v0.3.0), regression test suite (tests/test_regression.py) with 84 tests, and just generate-fixture target. All 600 tests pass.

title: Add release candidate workflow
description:
Add local tooling and CI support for a release candidate (RC) workflow.

## Local tooling (justfile targets)

### `just rc <bump>`
Single command, no SHA needed (uses HEAD).

1. Calculate next version from latest git tag (e.g. 0.1.8 + patch → 0.1.9)
2. If unreleased RC already exists for that version, ignore bump and increment RC number (v0.1.9-rc.2). To abandon the series and start higher, pass a different bump (e.g. `just rc minor` → 0.2.0-rc.1)
3. Always regenerate the regression fixture for this version and commit it
4. Tag HEAD as `v0.1.9-rc.N`, push tag
5. CI triggers automatically

### `just release`
Single command, no args (finds RC on HEAD).

1. Find RC tag on HEAD — fail if none exist
2. Derive release version from RC tag (v0.1.9-rc.1 → v0.1.9)
3. Tag HEAD as `v0.1.9`, push tag
4. CI triggers automatically → builds, releases, updates homebrew

## CI changes (release.yml)

Two homebrew formulas for two channels:

### RC tags (`v*-rc.*`)
- Set `prerelease: true` on GitHub release
- Update `Formula/dogcatwindowbed.rb` in homebrew-tap (edge/RC channel)

### Release tags (`v*` without -rc)
- Create full GitHub release (existing behavior)
- Update `Formula/dogcat.rb` in homebrew-tap (stable channel)

## Edge cases
- `just release` with no RC on HEAD → clear error
- Multiple RC tags for different version lines on HEAD → error, ask user to specify
- Successive RCs: bump arg only matters for first RC of a version; subsequent ones auto-increment RC number

Dependencies:
  → dogcat-549m (blocks)

title: Store dogcat version in JSONL records
description: Each record written to issues.jsonl should include a field (e.g. dcat_version) capturing the dogcat version that produced it. This aids debugging format issues, data migrations, and understanding which features were available when a record was created. Currently no version info is persisted in the storage format.
close_reason: Added dcat_version field to all JSONL records (issues, dependencies, links) with backward-compatible loading

title: Show issue details in dcat blocked output
description: dcat blocked currently only shows issue IDs and their blocking relationships. It should include additional context like title, type, priority, and status — similar to what dcat list displays — so users don't have to run a separate command to understand what's blocked.
close_reason: Blocked command now shows full issue details (title, type, priority) for both blocked and blocker issues using format_issue_brief, with tests to ensure it stays in sync with list output.

title: Add 'in-review' status shortcut command (dcat in-review <id>)
close_reason: Added dcat in-review listing command and ir/ip status shortcuts

title: Add 'dcat ip' alias for in-progress and 'dcat ir' alias for in-review
close_reason: Added dcat ip and dcat ir hidden shortcut commands

title: Make positional arg optional in dcat create and add --title flag
close_reason: Made positional arg optional and added --title flag to create, c, and add commands

title: Keep CHANGELOG.md updated with each release
description: Ensure CHANGELOG.md stays up to date. Each meaningful change (features, bug fixes, breaking changes) should be documented in the changelog before release.

title: Support bulk delete: allow multiple issue IDs in dcat delete
description: Currently dcat delete only accepts a single ISSUE_ID argument. It should accept multiple IDs so you can run e.g. dcat delete id1 id2 id3 to delete several issues at once.
close_reason: Implemented bulk delete support - delete command now accepts multiple issue IDs

title: Add dcat deferred shortcut command
description:
Add a `dcat deferred` command that lists all issues with status `deferred`, following the same pattern as `dcat in-progress` and `dcat in-review`. Should include:
- Viewer command: `dcat deferred` — lists deferred issues sorted by priority, with `--json` support
- Setter shortcut: `dcat defer <issue_id>` — sets an issue's status to deferred (hidden command, like `ir`/`ip`)
- Tests for both commands
close_reason: Added dcat deferred viewer and dcat defer shortcut commands with tests

title: Display labels as comma-separated list instead of individual brackets
description: In dcat list output, labels are currently shown as [label1] [label2] [label3]. Change the format to [label1, label2, label3] for a cleaner, more compact display.
close_reason: Labels now display as comma-separated list in brief/tree format

title: Rename --no-agent to --manual
description:
Rename the --no-agent flag to --manual across the codebase for clearer semantics. 'manual' positively describes what the issue is (requires human action) rather than what it isn't (not for agents).

Changes needed:
- CLI flags: --no-agent → --manual, --no-agent/--agent toggle → --manual/--no-manual
- Metadata key: no_agent → manual
- Keep --agent-only as-is (still clear: show only what agents can work on)
- Update help text, tests, prime output
- Handle backward compatibility for existing issues with no_agent metadata key
close_reason: Renamed --no-agent to --manual across CLI, storage, tests, and docs

title: Add manual checkbox in dcat edit/new UI, to the right of Priority
description: Add a 'Manual' checkbox to the Textual TUI editor (both edit and new issue screens), positioned to the right of the Priority selector. This lets users toggle the manual flag visually instead of only via the CLI flag.
close_reason: Added Manual checkbox in TUI editor next to Priority

title: Show [manual] tag in dcat list output
description: When listing issues with dcat list, issues marked as manual should display a [manual] tag so it's immediately visible which issues require human action.
close_reason: Added yellow [manual] tag in list, table, and tree views

title: dcat edit issue picker should show tags and labels like dcat list
close_reason: Added labels and manual flag to _make_issue_label in edit.py

title: Support space-separated labels in addition to comma-separated
close_reason: Added parse_labels() helper that splits on commas and/or spaces. Updated all 5 call sites and help text. 15 unit tests + 3 CLI integration tests added.

title: Add dcat manual shortcut command
description:
Add a `dcat manual` command that lists all issues marked as manual, following the same pattern as `dcat in-progress` and `dcat in-review`. Should include:
- Viewer command: `dcat manual` — lists manual issues sorted by priority, with `--json` support
- Setter shortcut: `dcat mark-manual <issue_id>` — marks an issue as manual (hidden command, like `ir`/`ip`)
- Tests for both commands
close_reason: Added dcat manual viewer and dcat mark-manual shortcut commands with tests

title: Support closing multiple issues in one dcat close command
description: dcat delete accepts multiple issue IDs (ISSUE_IDS...) but dcat close only accepts a single ISSUE_ID. For consistency and convenience, dcat close should accept variadic issue IDs so you can run e.g. dcat close id1 id2 id3 --reason "Done".
close_reason: Implemented variadic close matching delete pattern

title: Expand regression tests to cover untested model fields and recent features
description:
The regression tests in tests/test_regression.py only verify minimal loading: issues exist, a few issue types/statuses, dependencies, links, and comments. Many model fields and recent features are not covered, meaning regressions could go undetected.

Key gaps:
- **Issue fields**: priority, labels, owner, parent, description, design, acceptance, notes, close_reason, external_ref, duplicate_of, metadata
- **Audit trail**: created_by, updated_by, closed_by, deleted_by, closed_at, deleted_at
- **Additional enums**: STORY/CHORE/SUBTASK/QUESTION/DRAFT types; IN_REVIEW/BLOCKED/DEFERRED/TOMBSTONE statuses
- **Tombstone/soft-delete**: deleted issues with original_type, delete_reason
- **Parent-child**: parent field and get_children() method
- **Dependency/link details**: DependencyType preservation, link_type values, reverse lookups (get_dependents, get_incoming_links)
- **Recent features**: record_type discriminator, dcat_version on records, priority string names, flexible label parsing
close_reason: Added 21 new regression tests covering issue fields, audit trail, tombstones, parent-child, dependency types, and get() lookups. Total: 28 tests per fixture, 434 across all 14 fixtures.

title: Split test targets: separate regression tests from fast tests
description: Split the justfile test target into three: 'just test' (fast, excludes regression), 'just test-regression' (regression only), and 'just test-all' (everything). Updated CLAUDE.md with guidance on when to use each target.
close_reason: Implemented: justfile now has test, test-regression, and test-all targets. CLAUDE.md updated with usage guidance.

title: Improve test coverage from 78% to 90%+
close_reason: Coverage improved from 78% to 90% with 1180 tests passing

title: Add custom shell completions for dynamic values
description:
Typer's built-in shell completion works for subcommands and flags, but doesn't offer completions for dynamic values. Add custom autocompletion callbacks for:

- Issue IDs (e.g. `dcat show <TAB>`, `dcat update <TAB>`, `dcat close <TAB>`)
- Statuses (`--status <TAB>` → open, in_progress, in_review, closed, etc.)
- Types (`--type <TAB>` → bug, feature, task, question, etc.)
- Priorities (`--priority <TAB>` → 1, 2, 3, etc.)
- Labels (`--label <TAB>` → existing labels in the project)

title: Add CLI command aliases: l, lt, rc, b, d
description:
Add shorthand command aliases to cli.py:
- dcat l → dcat list -tree
- dcat lt → dcat list --table
- dcat rc → dcat recently-closed
- dcat b → dcat blocked
- dcat d → dcat deferred

Follow existing alias patterns (e.g. 'c' for create, 'e' for edit).
close_reason: Added all 5 aliases (l, lt, rc, b, d) with 8 tests

title: Deduplicate CLI command alias parameter lists
description: cli.py is ~3600 lines. The command aliases (create_alias, create_alias_add) at lines 964-1186 duplicate entire parameter lists (~200 lines of pure duplication). Factor shared params into a helper or use Typer's callback pattern to reduce duplication.
close_reason: Added _make_alias() helper to deduplicate CLI alias parameter lists. Replaced 5 alias functions (c, add, l, lt, n) with programmatic alias registration. Net reduction of 288 lines.

title: Move archive logic into JSONLStorage
description: The archive command (cli.py:3543-3560) directly manipulates storage internals: storage._issues, storage._dependencies, storage._links, and storage._base_lines. This should be a method on JSONLStorage to maintain encapsulation. If storage internals change, archive silently breaks.
close_reason: Archive state update moved to storage.remove_archived()

title: Move doctor storage access behind public API
description: The doctor command accesses storage._issues and storage._dependencies (cli.py:2769, 2789) directly. Same encapsulation concern as the archive command. Expose public methods for uniqueness checking and dependency integrity validation.
close_reason: Doctor now uses public storage API methods

title: Add file locking to JSONL writes
description: No file locking on issues.jsonl. Two concurrent dcat commands could interleave appends and corrupt a line. The stream watcher has retry logic (stream.py:197-208) suggesting concurrent access is expected. Consider fcntl.flock or advisory locking on writes.
close_reason: Added fcntl.flock advisory locking on JSONL writes

title: Add parent-child index to storage
description: get_children (storage.py:883) scans all issues linearly - O(n). Not indexed like dependencies/links. Inconsistent with the indexing strategy used for deps (_deps_by_issue) and links (_links_by_from). Add a _children_by_parent index dict.
close_reason: Completed

title: Add cycle protection to get_dependency_chain
description: get_dependency_chain (deps.py:225-241) has no cycle protection. If cycles exist (despite the guard on creation), this recurses infinitely and will crash with RecursionError. Should add a visited set parameter.
close_reason: Fixed: added _visited set to prevent infinite recursion on cycles

title: Optimize StreamEmitter to parse only new lines
description: StreamEmitter._handle_file_change (stream.py:199) re-creates an entire JSONLStorage on every file change event, re-parsing the full file. For a watcher that fires on every append, this is expensive. Consider tracking file position and only parsing new lines.
close_reason: StreamEmitter now does incremental parsing of new lines

title: Validate .dogcatrc path stays within project boundary
description: Path traversal via .dogcatrc (config.py:36-48). A malicious .dogcatrc containing ../../../../etc/something resolves to an arbitrary directory. parse_dogcatrc does resolve() but only checks is_dir() - it doesn't verify the resolved path stays within a reasonable boundary. For a git-committed file that others clone, an attacker who gets a .dogcatrc into a repo could redirect storage reads to any directory on a collaborator's machine.
close_reason: Fixed: added relative_to() boundary check in parse_dogcatrc

title: Escape Rich markup in issue titles for table display
description: No Rich markup sanitization on issue titles/descriptions. A title containing [red]malicious[/red] renders with Rich formatting in table view (cli.py:382-384). Cosmetic, not a security vuln, but a curious user could mess with display. Use Rich's escape() or Text() to prevent markup interpretation in user-supplied content.
close_reason: Rich markup in titles/labels now escaped

title: Fix _set_status writing 'operator' instead of 'updated_by'
description: _set_status (cli.py:2295) passes 'operator' as an update key but 'operator' is not in UPDATABLE_FIELDS (storage.py:439-465). The update() method silently ignores unknown keys (storage.py:491-492). This means the operator is never actually stored - status changes silently lose attribution. Should use 'updated_by' instead.
close_reason: Fixed: changed 'operator' key to 'updated_by' in _set_status

title: Fix remove_cmd passing str to delete's list[str] parameter
description: remove_cmd (cli.py:1878-1899) takes a single issue_id: str but delegates to delete() which takes issue_ids: list[str]. The call on line 1893 passes issue_id=issue_id. This works because Typer converts it to a single-element list, but it's fragile and will break if delete's signature changes.
close_reason: Fixed remove_cmd to pass issue_id as list

title: Fix _close_one and _delete_one typing storage as object
description: _close_one and _delete_one (cli.py:1738, 1805) type the storage parameter as object then use type: ignore[union-attr]. These should accept JSONLStorage for proper type safety.
close_reason: Typed storage as JSONLStorage instead of object

title: Fix export command emitting duplicate dependency/link entries
description: The export command (cli.py:2864-2937) iterates over all issues and calls get_dependencies + get_links per issue. A dependency between A and B appears when iterating both A and B, creating duplicate entries. The dedup only works because the output is informational. Should deduplicate or iterate deps/links directly.
close_reason: Export now iterates deps/links directly via public properties

title: Enforce UPDATABLE_FIELDS allowlist in storage.update()
description: The comments field is updated through storage.update() by passing the entire comments list (cli.py:2989). The comments key is not in UPDATABLE_FIELDS but it's set via setattr because hasattr(issue, 'comments') is true (storage.py:493, 502). This bypasses the allowlist - any field that exists on the Issue dataclass can be modified via update() even if not in UPDATABLE_FIELDS. The hasattr check should be removed or the guard should be 'if key not in self.UPDATABLE_FIELDS: continue' with comments added to the allowlist.
close_reason: Fixed: removed hasattr bypass, added comments to UPDATABLE_FIELDS

title: Switch from toml to tomli/tomli-w
description: The toml package (pyproject.toml:12) is unmaintained. Python 3.11+ has tomllib in stdlib. Since we require >=3.10, switch to tomli (read) and tomli-w (write) which are the maintained replacements. tomli: https://pypi.org/project/tomli/ tomli-w: https://pypi.org/project/tomli-w/ For Python 3.11+ can conditionally use stdlib tomllib for reads and only need tomli-w for writes.
close_reason: Switched from toml to tomllib/tomli + tomli-w

title: Show blocking issue IDs next to blocked status in tree view
description: When using 'dcat list --tree', blocked issues show the ■ symbol but don't indicate what is blocking them. The 'dcat blocked' command already shows this info (e.g. 'blocked by ● [3] dogcat-345d: ...'), so the tree view should also display the blocking issue ID(s) inline, e.g. '■ [2] dogcat-1a88: Remove uv dependency from Homebrew formula [chore] (blocked by dogcat-345d)'.
close_reason: Added blocked_by_map to format_issue_brief and format_issue_tree to show [blocked by: id1, id2] inline

title: Show blocking issue IDs in table view for blocked issues
description: Similar to dogcat-5iml for the tree view, the table view (dcat list --table) should show which issues are blocking a blocked issue. Add a 'Blocked By' column or inline the info so users can see at a glance what is blocking each issue.
close_reason: Added Blocked By column to format_issue_table, conditionally shown when blocked issues exist

title: Remove redundant test fixtures and skip schema-identical tags in generator
description: Analyzed the JSONL schema across all 16 git tags (v0.1.0–v0.5.2) and found only 4 schema transitions. Removed 9 redundant fixture files (v0.1.1–v0.1.9) that were identical to v0.1.0. Updated generate_fixture.py with a SKIP_TAGS set so running without arguments skips tags with redundant schemas (v0.1.1–v0.1.9, v0.5.1–v0.5.2). Explicit tag arguments bypass the skip list. Regression tests pass with 5 remaining fixtures covering all distinct schema versions.

title: Add 'pr' command combining in-progress and in-review listings
description: Add a new 'dcat pr' command that displays in-progress issues followed by in-review issues in a single output. This provides a quick dashboard view of all active work. Should print the in-progress section first, then the in-review section, with appropriate headers to distinguish the two groups.
close_reason: Implemented pr command showing in-progress and in-review issues together

title: Add 'recently-added' command with 'ra' alias
description: Add a new 'dcat recently-added' command (with hidden 'ra' alias) that shows recently created issues in ascending order (oldest first), mirroring the pattern of the existing 'recently-closed' command. Should support --limit/-n, --json, and --dogcats-dir options.
close_reason: Implemented recently-added command with ra alias, excludes closed issues, uses format_issue_brief, newest first

title: Tweak `bd prime` to better instruct the agent in how to deal with blockers and child/parent relations
Fix recently-closed sort order to show newest first (match recently-added)
description: recently-closed sorts ascending (oldest first) while recently-added sorts descending (newest first). Flip recently-closed to show newest first for consistency.
close_reason: Flipped sort order to descending (newest first) to match recently-added.

title: Refactor fixture generator from denylist to allowlist
description: Changed tests/generate_fixture.py to use an allowlist (SCHEMA_TAGS) instead of a denylist (SKIP_TAGS). New tags no longer need to be manually added to a skip set — only tags with actual schema changes are added to the allowlist. Also removed the unused _get_all_tags helper.
close_reason: Replaced SKIP_TAGS denylist with SCHEMA_TAGS allowlist in tests/generate_fixture.py

title: Add table of contents to README
close_reason: Added table of contents to README

title: Align CLI options across create, update, and edit commands
description:
Several fields are inconsistent across the three commands:

Missing from both create and update (but supported by edit):
- --design
- --external-ref

Missing from update (but supported by create):
- --depends-on
- --blocks
- --editor / -e

Missing from create (but supported by update):
- --duplicate-of

All three commands should support the full set of relevant fields for consistency.
close_reason: Added --design, --external-ref, --duplicate-of to create; --design, --external-ref, --depends-on, --blocks, --editor to update

title: Update dcat prime output to reflect aligned create/update options
description: After the CLI options are aligned across create, update, and edit, update the dcat prime workflow guide to document the new options available on create and update (e.g. --design, --external-ref, --depends-on, --blocks on update, etc.).
close_reason: Updated prime output to reference full shared options list

title: Fix dcat show formatting for description, notes, acceptance and design
description: dcat show displays notes/acceptance inline and doesn't show design at all. Should format these as separate sections with headers and dividers.
close_reason: Added design field to show output, reformatted description/notes/acceptance/design as separate sections, styled all keys as bold cyan

title: Split cli.py into cli/ package

close_reason: Split cli.py (4074 lines) into cli/ package with 14 focused submodules. All 941 tests pass.

title: Write cli/__init__.py facade and delete old cli.py
description: Create the __init__.py facade: define app, call register(app) from all submodules, define main(), re-export format_issue_brief, find_dogcats_dir, get_storage, get_default_operator for backward compatibility. Delete old cli.py. ~70 lines.

title: Fix pyright errors
description: There are 88 pyright errors remaining after adding venvPath/venv configuration. These are pre-existing type errors in tests and source files (not related to orjson). Clean them up to get a clean pyright run.
close_reason: Fixed all 81 pyright errors: excluded auto-generated _version.py, added typed default factories, cast Select widget queries, annotated test variables, and added None guards for optional datetime comparisons.

title: Set up local multi-Python test harness
description: Set up a local test harness for running the test suite against multiple Python versions: 3.10, 3.11, 3.12, 3.13, and 3.14. The project already requires-python >= 3.10 (pyproject.toml). Currently tests run via 'just test' using a single venv. We need a way to easily run the full test suite against all supported versions locally.
acceptance:
- Can run tests against Python 3.10, 3.11, 3.12, 3.13, and 3.14 locally with a single command
- Uses tox or nox (or similar) to orchestrate multi-version testing
- Integrates with the existing justfile (e.g. 'just test-matrix' or similar)
- Works with the existing uv-based dependency management
- Documents how to install the required Python versions (e.g. via pyenv or uv python install)
notes: Consider using tox-uv or nox with uv backend for consistency with the existing uv workflow. Python 3.14 is in pre-release so the harness should tolerate failures on that version gracefully.
close_reason: Set up tox + tox-uv multi-Python test harness (3.10-3.14) with editable installs, coverage support, and justfile integration

title: Add feature_flags.py module with FeatureFlag enum and feature_enabled()
description:
Add a dedicated feature_flags.py module that serves as a registry for all feature flags. The module should contain:

1. A FeatureFlag str enum defining all possible flags (initially empty or with a placeholder)
2. A feature_enabled(flag: FeatureFlag, *, default: bool = False) function that checks DCAT_FEATURE_<NAME> env vars
3. A 'dcat features' CLI command that lists all flags with their env var name and current status

Design:
- Flags are checked via env var DCAT_FEATURE_<NAME>=1 (also accepts 'true', 'yes')
- The enum is the single source of truth — type-safe, grep-friendly, self-documenting
- Later extensible to also read from config.toml without changing call sites

title: Add manual flag to demo issues
description: Add metadata.manual=True to 'Review security policies' and 'Configure backup strategy' demo issues in src/dogcat/demo.py. These are good candidates for the --manual flag since they require human judgment/action. This ensures the demo exercises the manual/agent-only filtering feature.
close_reason: Added manual flag to 'Review security policies' and 'Configure backup strategy' demo issues via metadata

title: cgst
Add feature_flags.py module with FeatureFlag enum and feature_enabled()
description:
Add a dedicated feature_flags.py module that serves as a registry for all feature flags. The module should contain:

1. A FeatureFlag str enum defining all possible flags (initially empty or with a placeholder)
2. A feature_enabled(flag: FeatureFlag, *, default: bool = False) function that checks DCAT_FEATURE_<NAME> env vars
3. A 'dcat features' CLI command that lists all flags with their env var name and current status

Design:
- Flags are checked via env var DCAT_FEATURE_<NAME>=1 (also accepts 'true', 'yes')
- The enum is the single source of truth — type-safe, grep-friendly, self-documenting
- Later extensible to also read from config.toml without changing call sites

title: Interactive TUI dashboard (dcat tui)
description: Feature-gated interactive TUI dashboard for browsing and managing issues. Gated behind DCAT_FEATURE_TUI=1. Current implementation provides a DataTable-based issue browser with keybindings for refresh (r) and edit (e). Future work: search/filter, inline status changes, issue creation, detail panel.

title: Add custom shell completions for dynamic values
description:
Typer's built-in shell completion works for subcommands and flags, but doesn't offer completions for dynamic values. Add custom autocompletion callbacks for:

- Issue IDs (e.g. `dcat show <TAB>`, `dcat update <TAB>`, `dcat close <TAB>`)
- Statuses (`--status <TAB>` → open, in_progress, in_review, closed, etc.)
- Types (`--type <TAB>` → bug, feature, task, question, etc.)
- Priorities (`--priority <TAB>` → 1, 2, 3, etc.)
- Labels (`--label <TAB>` → existing labels in the project)
close_reason: Completed

title: Unify TUI design with dcat new and dcat edit
description: The TUI dashboard (dcat tui) should share the same visual design language and Textual components as the existing 'dcat new' and 'dcat edit' commands (IssueEditorApp in edit.py). Currently the TUI detail screen uses plain text while the editor uses styled widgets. Refactor to share common UI components, styling (CSS), and layout patterns across all three surfaces.
